Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Kantavuus vaihteli - välillä meni läpi, välillä jalka upposi 10 - 40 cm. Maa kivirakkaa. Satulan kohdalta eli paikasta, jossa on eniten lunta. Ohuemman lumipeitteen alueilla ei kantavuutta.

No skiing today, but always fun to see a CTV. Accessed by hiking up south slopes from Ohio Gulch. Probably not enough snow volume remaining in track to impact East Fork / Triumph below, if it did slide. Weak crust holding things together, and cool weather forecasted for the coming week, should keep similar slopes from becoming ugly again soon. No obvious evidence of preferential flow.
ALP, lästluttning. Utkant av SZ och 5 m från ca 3-4 v gammal brottkant ca 20 cm djup. Foot pen ibland ca 70 cm, ibland 10.
vindbyar som drev lite snö. ALP, läsluttning, blockterrräng
ALP, läsluttning, i höjd med SZ ovan klippartiet (och mitt i detta).

Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The goal of this pit was to determine whether a graupel layer exists at the bottom of this new snow in our zone. At least in this location, it does not. New snow seemed generally unconsolidated at this elevation. The sun was in and out, mixed with lots of cloud cover and occasional light snow showers. Very unconsolidated (F-) large (3mm+) rounding facets were found below the pit, but may be attributed to large boulders (1M) interspersed in the area.
Moderate wind and very light snow when pit was finished at 3PM.

Healthy size 2 in cross-loaded alpine start zone released Na and subsequently pulled another size 2 farther down path running into upper runout on WNW aspect behind Hudson Bay Mountain. No Sc attempts today and MOD E-NE winds at ridgetop transporting snow to western aspects.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Testprofil 150 m från Sa2 som gick 2018-03-03. Sprickan i förlängda brottkanten ända fram till profil, där flaket är lite djupare än var lavinen startat. ALP. Läsluttning. Stor ryggformation.

Rolig vind og le tett inntil veg. Sporene og snøprofilen fra i går hadde ikke føyka ned. Lenger nordvest mot Vakkerjordvatna, mer vind, vindtegn i snøen og flakdannelse. Fortsatt myke flak (4F) Relativt glatt snøoverflate i utløsningsområdene. Mer vindtegn på flatene.

No new Na slab avalanche observations nor Sc attempts/results. Moderate east wind at ridgetop having some reverse loading effect. Cold temperatures helping to tighten in previous storm instabilities but still not trusting large northern features. Hs = 460 cm at site. TD = 159 cm.
Temp was taken from CAIC point forecast at Aspen Highlands. Felt much warmer~50
Felt warmer than 36 degrees F. Temp came from point forecast for Aspen Highlands.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The ground is rock covered with no grass The avalanche is a small soft slab released probably during snow fall the day before or during night The layer @205 contains sand and it is red colored. The temperature @ the ground interface is not around zero.
Ny rimfrost på ytan, 3 mm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug in crown of deep slab avalanche that occurred on March 22. Avalanche failed at base of remains of Feb facet layer (32-40cm). Near treeline terrain.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on similar slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Shallower snowpack on the west side of runs in this region. 500 feet lower on an adjacent run a rider knocked out a small avalanche when he isolated the far side of a steep rollover (cookie cutter between ski tracks). SS-ARu-R1-D1 down 25cm. slab dimensions were roughly 10m wide by 20m long. slope angle was in the high 30's.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Large opening the the trees, at top of treeline

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Collapsing, localized
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Winds were loading slopes on all aspects and elevations. Our pit location was a little sheltered so there wasn't much loading in this specific spot. We observed naturals and shooting cracks on heavier wind loaded slopes. CPST 98/100 end @ 318
BTL - så här är det generellt i BTL. På vindutsatta platser hårdare ovanpå men inte något drevsnöflak; mer vindpinad yta.
Klar och kall morgon vid Norska gränsen. Stilla i dalgången och kanske 4-5m/s NW på kalfjället.
TL. Läsluttning. Gräs och låga buskar. Grävd 200 m från Na2 som gick 2018-03-26. 2 st ECT då första blev ECTPV, så andra ECT bara för att testa drevsnön.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent activity on similar slopes; Recent activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: On the flank of a bowl north of Tennesfjellet

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: I dug adjacent my DK 2 pit. My primary goal was to observe how the new snow bonded to the old and to look for any near crust faceting. The new/old snow seemed very well bonded, and I was unable to find any faceting near the two crusts that I observed. Stability tests yielded results similar to what was seen in Killebrew and Mott on 3/25/18 (storm snow sloughing). Surface hoar persists, even on wind/sun exposed slopes.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on similar slopes; We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: NO CO, CR, AV. Pit very similar to previous day's pit on similar aspect and elevation, except for the 'stepped' fracture.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Poor pit location
We skied slope
We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Overall, very little wind effect with the new snow. However, on SW Meridian, we were able to ski cut some 15 cm deep soft slabs, over a harder m/f crust, which were more sensitive/ running short distances.
Also, some small wet loose activity was noted on the steep solar aspects around 2pm, with greenhouse warming and calm winds.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Recent activity on similar slopes; Recent activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: ALP. Ovan SZ. Läsluttning. Stenig mark. Drevade lite under tiden.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Highly variable structure in the region. This area had a considerably deeper snowpack and harder layers than most of the runs we skied. More typical structure was 10-15 cm of DF and NSF on top of a 5cm crust with a thick layer of 1mm NSF below that crust. NO, CR, AV on runs in that zone. Slow to Fast facet sluffing on slopes >40 degrees

New cornice formation. Ski pen variable from 0 (supportable rain crust on ridge crest) to 20 cm. Minor cracking under ski on new wind slabs. Tilt tests also revealed weaknesses in new snow 80-85 cm.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Möjligen har SH 17 mars inte blivit effektivt begravd här.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Large outflow winds from the end of last week (Weds/Thurs) have scoured the region and created large sastrugi and the occasional breakable wind crust.

Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank
Recent activity on similar slopes; Recent activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpack isothermal, varied from moist to wet based upon structure. 10cm supportable crust from rain event on 22 March. Interesting to conduct tests on structured isothermal snow that has seen recent wet slab avalanching. Exhaustive pit analysis not conducted; more interested in comparing ECT and PST results for known culprit in many avalanches this late winter/early spring.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Cracking; Recent activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 6in. new snow this morning. Stopped snowing 30-45 minutes before pit. Wind increasing to strong.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Maa kivirakkaa. Ilmatieteenlaitoksen stressitesti 45 cm pinnasta 1 laatikko/2,5 kg. Vesiarvotesti 1 putki/45 cm/104. Lähes koko lumipeite on käytännössä fasettia. Maasta puolimetriä ylös fasettikerrokset ja hauraat korppukerrokset vaihtelevat muutaman sentin välein.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: I was quite surprised that the ECT column failed on isolation.

Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Looking for spatial extent of rain/snow line and snowpack saturation levels. Above ~9500 ft in the upper cottonwoods seems to be the level at which water stayed within the new snow and did not percolate into the lower portions of the snowpack. Did not dig to ground.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Skies clearing, trace of graupel still falling. Winds calm where pit was dug (below treeline sheltered area) but clouds moving fast up high.

Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: ALP. Läsluttning. Sten. I västra sidan av brottkanten till Sa3 (180322). Dimensioner 250 m bred; 170 cm djup som mest. På djupare delar av brottkant är har K-flaket (på 4-13 cm) ytterligare en dryg meter P-flak ovanpå sig.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Sky obscured, low cloud and currently snowing and blowing SW. Blowing snow loads of up to 15cm observed. HST appears to be bonding moderately well, No slab quality noted at this time. Good skiing on slope.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pack consisted of trace PP surfce form on a 2cm MFcr that fails on isolation. Some DF present in upper pack other wise mid pack consists of various FCxr layers with multiple decomposing crusts. DH 5-7mm still present at ground.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Recent activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope
Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 1.8 inches SWE deposited since final day of high pressure on 3/15. Numerous Class 1-2 Natural and Skier triggered avalanches reported on S through NE facing slopes at Middle and Upper Elevations in the Teton Range everyday since 3/15. Problem layer: Buried Suncrust with Facets 45cm down.

Cracking; We skied slope
Collapsing, widespread; Cracking

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug to examine the March 13 graupel layer on top of melt freeze crust combo that has caused deep slab avalanches in the Mt. Rose area. Layer was found in this area but was nonreactive with snowpack tests. Snow pit dug in near treeline terrain just below ridgeline.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit is at the crown of a skier triggered avalanche that occurred on March 17. The weak layer was the graupel on top of the melt-freeze crust at 200 cm. It varied in depth today from 60 to 90 cm below the surface. As I was climbing back out of the crown, I triggered a large whumpf that caused the slope ablve the crown to collapse but it did not slide. I was on belay.
